title: CTRL0000083783 - Transcribed Interview of Julie T. Radford, (May 24, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 3:01 p.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
So this is a transcribed interview conducted by the House Select
Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol pursuant to
Ms. Radford, thank you for joining us.
Could you please say your name and spell it for the record?
This will be a staff-led interview.
investigative counsel with the staff of the select committee.
I have with me by Webex
Members may choose to join the interview, but as of now, there are none on.
any do join, I'll let you know, and they can ask a question if they so choose.
otherwise, it will be myself and p o s s i b l y - asking questions.
I know you have Mr. Benson with you.
But, Mr. Benson, could you please just note your appearance for the record?
Daniel Benson with Julie Radford from the firm Kasowitz Benson.
Ms. Radford, I'll just go over a few ground rules to help things go smoothly today.
There is an official reporter who's writing down what you're saying, creating a
So if you could, just wait to answer a question until I finish asking before you
And I'll wait until you finish your answer before I ask the next
And if you respond in a nonverbal way, like shaking your head or nodding your
head, the reporter can't transcribe that.
So I'll just follow up and ask you to say yes or
We ask today that you provide answers that are complete based on your best
recollection of the events we'll discuss.
clear, just tell us and we'll do our best to rephrase it so it is clear.
the answer or you don't remember, just say so.
If a question I ask or someone else asks is not
If you need to take any breaks for comfort or to talk to Mr. Benson privately, let us
know, and we're happy to accommodate that.
We can turn the cameras off and go on
Throughout the interview, there may be times when I show you exhibits.
colleague of mine will put them up on a screen.
you could get a chance to review them in advance.
I sent them to Mr. Benson yesterday so
But putting that aside, if you need more time to look at them when they're on the
screen, take as much time as you need, and let me know when you're ready to answer
I also want to remind you, as we do all witnesses before we start, that it's unlawful
to deliberately provide false information to Congress and that to do so could result in
So any questions before we get started?
If you could, when we progress through the interview, if you could
lean closer, I think it picks up the audio better for you.
I want to note for the record that you're appearing today voluntarily,
without the need for a subpoena.
How old are you, Ms. Radford?
And what is your highest level of education?
What type of work do you do, just as a general matter?
I'm doing consulting, primarily around communications and reputation risk
Is it right that you served as chief of staff for lvanka Trump during her time in
the White House, at least through the end of the Trump administration in January of
Approximately what year and month did you start in your role as chief of
staff for Ms. Trump, as best you can remember?
March -- I started as chief of staff with her in March of 2017.
the White House in February of 2017.
For that one month before you transitioned over, what was your role?
I was working -- I actually didn't have a title.
Powell doing economic initiatives and family policy.
Now, focusing on the end of President Trump's administration, really from
the election through to January of 2021, what as a general matter were your
responsibilities as chief of staff for Ms. Trump?
If they were different during that time, that's really what we're focused on.
But just for those 3 months, just what were your general responsibilities?
Policy, transitioning our office, doing wrap-up memos, helping off-board our
We did some -- if I remember correctly, there was a budget or resolution or
something going through at the time.
So working on some legislative stuff around that.
With regard to the transition and the wrap-up, as you talked about, when
did those efforts begin after the election, as best you can remember?
I would say probably mid-November, the stuff I was looped in on where kind
of the points for each primary office, so the policy offices and whatnot, were brought in
to start -- we were given a guide on how to start working on transition memos and
wrap-up materials simultaneously just for Presidential records and stuff, making sure that
our team -- I made sure our team knew what they needed to do.
And just logistically, your office space, was it in the West Wing?
And where was it in relation to Ms. Trump's office?
And approximately how many feet away was your desk from Ms. Trump's
No, I mean, you walked out of my door, you probably walked 10 feet and
you were -- or, less, 5 feet -- and then you were in her office.
vaccine came out and so the pandemic was still kind of in the middle of it.
Were you coming into work every day, or were you working remotely?
was your work schedule like as a general matter?
And at this time they were talking about -- it was right around the time the
So right after the election, for two and a half weeks, I didn't go into the
And then I was in the office.
Election night, were you at the White House?
Were you there through the speech that President Trump gave in the early
Were you involved in any discussions with the President about what he
Did you hear anybody else giving the President advice about what he should
To your knowledge, did Ms. Trump speak with her father about what he
think it was about what he should say.
I know she spoke with her father.
If you recall, during his remarks in the early morning hours of November 4th,
President Trump said that he did win the election but that the votes that were coming in
were effectively a big fraud, a major fraud on the American public.
Do you remember just in sum and substance that he said those things that night?
Well, going forward from that night, and understanding you were at home
for two and a half weeks after that, do you know whether Ms. Trump was involved in the
efforts of President Trump and those working on his behalf to challenge the results of the
Did she ever share with you her views on those efforts to challenge the
Did she ever share with you her views about the people that President
Trump was working with to challenge the election, whether that's Sidney Powell or Rudy
Giuliani or any other members of the team?
Did Ms. Trump ever express with you or share with you her views on
whether there, in fact, was fraud in the election?
We discussed whether or not there was fraud in the election, not so much
personal views but just the discussion that was happening around us, if that makes sense.
And to provide more color on those discussions, did the two of you discuss
whether the claims that were being made by President Trump and those on his behalf
No, just that things were being looked into.
I would say that was from
You're talking about election day through the day that the networks
declared that President Biden had won the election?
After that day, when President Biden was declared the winner, did you have
discussions with Ms. Trump about the continuing efforts --
-- of the Trump campaign to challenge the results?
Did she ever share with you whether she thought it was a good thing for her
father to continue challenging the election?
Did she ever -- were you ever present for or did Ms. Trump ever tell you that
she herself had a conversation with her father about whether he won or lost the election
And what did she tell you about her conversations with her father
about whether he had won or lost?
Just that she had talked to her father and that -- in the context of transition.
And what do you mean by that?
Proceeding with transition and having a smooth transition of power.
And what did her father tell her during that conversation?
She didn't relay anything from his perspective.
What was her perspective then that she shared with him and then told you
She talked about proceeding with the transition of power and a smooth
Just so I'm understanding, in other words --
[Inaudible] Biden, making sure that memos were done, information was
Approximately when was that conversation that she had with the President?
It was probably when I was back, so probably like in mid-November, maybe
I don't remember when Thanksgiving was that year.
Did Ms. Trump tell you that she was advising her father that he should allow
for the smooth transition of power or that she herself, within her area of responsibility,
was going to proceed with the transition?
simultaneously, our team should be working on transition.
That she believed there should be a smooth transition of power;
And do you know what prompted the need for Ms. Trump to have that
And why did she tell you about it?
I mean, it affected my day to day in that we had an entire policy portfolio
Did it affect your responsibilities or day
that we needed to make sure was categorized and left in a way that someone else could
pick it up and understand where certain things stood and be able to make decisions one
Did she tell you that President Trump in any way sought to keep her from
proceeding with the smooth transition of power?
So as far as you understood, you had the green light to proceed with that
Did that change at any point between then and when President Trump left
Now, I imagine you were aware, say, from mid-November through
January 6th, that President Trump and his team did continue to make efforts to challenge
election results, whether in court or otherwise.
I was aware by watching the news.
Did you ever speak with Ms. Trump about whether she should advise her
President -- her father, the President -- to stop those efforts and just move on?
Did anyone else within the White House, Ms. Trump excepted, ever relay to
you a conversation they had directly with President Trump between election day and
when he left office about whether he won or lost the election?
And prior to January 6th, were you privy to any discussion among White
House staff, Ms. Trump included, about Vice President Pence's role on January 6th at the
One of the three exhibits that I sent to Mr. Benson yesterday, we'll show it
Raiklin -- that's R-a-i-k-1-i-n -- sent on December 23rd of 2020 to several people.
you're among them and so is Ms. Trump.
Pence to refuse to receive, in the words of the proposal, the electoral votes from certain
And this is an email that a gentleman by the name of Ivan
And it's about a proposal for Vice President
Do you remember receiving this email or any communications like this about Vice
President Pence's authority with regard to the electoral votes?
Do you know who Mr. Raiklin is?
Do you remember doing anything just generally with respect to information
like this regarding the election and Ms. Trump?
So then looking forward to January 6th and the event at the Ellipse, you're
aware generally with the fact that the event occurred and that President Trump spoke at
How do you know Ms. Pierson?
I met her -- originally she --1 think it was maybe 2017, the first time I met
Someone invited us -- I mean, sorry, introduced us.
And one of the three exhibits I share, we don't need to bring it up unless you
would like me to, is just an email exchange you had with Ms. Pierson.
January 4th of 2021, and then you followed up on the 5th, about whether or not Ms.
Trump would speak at the event.
Do you remember speaking with Ms. Pierson about that?
I remember the email from her asking.
event at the time when she sent that email.
I didn't know anything about the
I responded the next day after trying to
figure out what the event was, what this rally was.
was -- what I gathered from scheduling was that there was a rally on the Ellipse.
And all I knew was that there
And you asked if you could give her a call to speak.
Did the two of you end
up speaking by phone as best you can remember?
I actually don't think we ended up speaking by phone.
How did the conversation end up between you and Ms. Pierson?
Ultimately, we know Ms. Trump didn't speak at the Ellipse rally.
what you talked to Ms. Pierson about concerning the event?
So I remember that I asked her to call me because I wanted to know where
the request for her to speak was coming from, just so I understood, and then telling her
that likely that she would not be -- she would not be speaking.
if she would attend or not.
Service, that they could plan like she was attending, but I wasn't 100 percent sure.
But for purposes of planning and because it involved Secret
And I can read from the email.
It might be helpful just to bring it up.
If we go to the bottom of the first page.
Can you see that, Ms. Radford?
We'll continue going on to the bottom of that first page to where
Ms. Pierson first writes to you, right there.
And you see that at -- in the first email she sends, she starts off, "POTUS
asked me if lvanka was speaking at his January 6th Stop the Steal event, and I wasn't sure
if she wanted to say a few words or not."
So in terms of you wanting to understand where the ask was coming from, did you
come to understand it was from the President himself?
Well, a lot of times people would email me and say the President
asked, because that would get -- that would then mean that she would -- might lean
asked or the President asked or her dad asked.
So I've gotten a lot of emails that say POTUS
So then I got the context, tried to figure out who else was speaking, which was
some of my questions, and then got back to her.
Now, the fact that Ms. Pierson characterized the event as a Stop the Steal
event, as you saw there in that first email she sent, did that raise any concern or thoughts
in your mind about whether this was an event that Ms. Trump would want to speak at,
I saw it and thought this is not something that she would want to speak at.
She didn't really speak that often at big rallies, and I think just probably the
In other words, stopping the steal relating to the supposed steal of the
And was it your understanding that Ms. Trump did not want to associate
with that Stop the Steal messaging and efforts?
Katrina ends up telling you that a few Congressmen, a few Senators, the
event organizer, and the boys -- that is, Ms. Trump's brothers -- might be speaking and
that it was supposed to be a small event, in her words.
Did any of that give you more comfort about whether Ms. Trump would be open
to speaking at this, or it was a nonstarter based on the Stop the Steal?
No, it wasn't -- I didn't need comfort.
I just knew it wasn't something that
she would want to be out there speaking at.
Did you confirm that with Ms. Trump herself and ask her if she would speak
at it, or did you just make the decision based on what you knew her position would be?
I think by the time I replied to Katrina I had not gotten in touch with her to
But I had, just knowing her, made the decision.
And, like I said, I said that she would attend, because from a logistical and security
perspective, it's easier to say she's not going to -- it's easier to pull her out of something
than to put her into something at the last minute from the perspective of Secret Service.
And they would stop asking and calling and emailing and texting if I just said, yes,
At what point, if ever, did you tell Ms. Trump that she had been asked to
speak and that you had told --
And did she agree with you when you said you had told
Ms. Pierson that she, Ms. Trump, would not be speaking?
Did she have any further discussion about the event at that point?
Now, the next day, as we understand it, you ended up going to the Ellipse
She just still wasn't sure if she would actually go to the event.
Do you remember approximately what time you got into work that day?
Was it earlier than normal or later or regular time?
And did you -- we understand that Ms. Trump spent time with her family and
President Trump in the residence that morning and then also in the Oval Office.
you aware that she was in those meetings with her family and the President that morning
I knew she had been in the Oval with her father and her brothers, because
someone had called me to let me know that her siblings were downstairs and if she
Before she left for that, did you already know that morning that Ms. Trump
was going to go to the rally or it was still an open question?
It was still a little bit of an open question.
There were a number chimes when just people
would want her to go places and we just hadn't made a decision one way or another.
How did you learn that, and when, that she had decided to go to the rally?
She came back up to her office for a couple of minutes.
video for someone's birthday or for a -- you know, somebody that had requested a video.
And then she said, "I'm going to go back downstairs.
know, like, you'll know if I'm going if I walk out.
So I went down to the cars.
Meet me out by the cars.
If not, just we're not going."
The time that when Ms. Trump came back upstairs, had she already been in
the meeting with her father and her siblings in the Oval Office by that point?
What, if anything, did she tell you at that time about what had happened in
What did her mood appear to be like at that time?
A little stressed but not -- like a little stressed.
So no mention of the call that took place between President Trump and Vice
President Pence while she was in the Oval Office at that time?
So as we understand it, did you go down and get in the car with
And Ms. Trump ended up coming with you to go to the Ellipse, right?
Did anybody else get in the car with you other than a Secret Service agent?
Within the car, did Ms. Trump share with you any more details about what
had happened or any details about what had happened in the Oval Office that morning?
That her dad had just had an upsetting conversation with the Vice President.
Upsetting for her, like it upset her, the conversation.
talking, I guess, between the two.
There was yelling maybe -- not yelling -- firm
Did she express that the conversation concerned what the Vice President
was going to do that day regarding the count of the election results?
No, she didn't get into those details.
And did you have any -- did she express why, other than the fact that the call
was heated, why it bothered her, why she was disturbed by the call?
Did she express any views on Mike Pence?
told someone else that day that Mike Pence is a good man, something to that effect.
Did she make any comments about her views on Vice President Pence?
I wouldn't say that she said -- I don't know if she said Mike Pence is a
good man, but she did just talk about how the call was upsetting and her dad was angry.
And she was visibly bothered by the direction of the call.
Did the call and how it went have anything to do with why Ms. Trump chose
to go to the rally from what she told you?
And why do you suspect as much?
Because I think she wanted to try to help keep her dad calm, if possible.
And so the relationship between Ms. Trump and her father, is she somehow
uniquely situated, based on your observations, to help keep her father calm?
would she -- I'm just trying to get a sense of why that would be something she felt she
could do that day based on what you know.
Just based on my observations, I think that sometimes there are times that
she can get through to her father when others can't or when others have hit a wall.
I think that's what -- why she went to the Ellipse that day.
What did she share with you about why it was concerning that her father
was upset or agitated after that call with Vice President Pence in relation to the Ellipse
Why did he have to be calmed down, I should say.
Well, she shared that he had called the Vice President a not -- an expletive
and what was going on in the office that he was angry and upset and people were
down, at least before he went onto stage.
And I think she could tell based on the conversations
And she felt like she might be able to help calm the situation
And the word that she relayed to you that the President called the Vice
President -- apologize for being impolite -- but do you remember what she said her father
I think we understand enough about what that word is.
to -- I won't make you say it.
And in terms of the misinformation that Ms. Trump was concerned about, what
I just -- she did not get specific.
There were just a lot of
people that were telling the President one thing or another thing.
wanted him to deliver a clean, good speech and leave and go back to the White House
And on that point, was there concern that Ms. Trump raised that the
President would verbally go after the Vice President at the speech at the Ellipse, in other
Was that something she expressed to you?
Did you hear anything at that time or before the President took the stage at
the Ellipse about his desire to go to the Capitol after he was done speaking?
When you got to the Ellipse, did you stay with Ms. Trump until the time that
the President went on the stage?
Yes, but I was about 15 feet away from her.
Did she, in fact, spend time with her father before he took the stage?
We've seen photos that suggest they were.
And did she stay pretty close to him throughout that time?
So consistent with what she had told you about wanting to try to be a
calming influence on him before he took the stage?
Were you able to observe anything about the President's mood before he
took the stage that told you whether he appeared calm or not calm?
To me, he seemed like he normally did before a rally.
lot of people out there cheering happily for him and excited for him.
didn't seem any different really than he had been at other -- when I've seen him at other
Now, Ms. Trump's siblings and their significant others were there as well in
the general area where you were, right?
Did you hear any of them talk about what had happened in the Oval Office?
Did you interact with him that morning
before the President took the stage?
Just briefly in the tent to say hi.
But nothing about what had happened in the Oval Office?
And the same question with respect to Eric Herschmann.
there, and did you have any interaction of substance with him?
After the President took the stage and before he came down after delivering
his remarks did you talk with Ms. Trump at all about what she said to her father while she
was with him there in the tent?
About what his mood was like and whether he had calmed down?
Were you able to hear the President's remarks as he was giving them or you
What were you doing during that time?
So after the President went onto stage, lvanka came in, asked me if there
was somewhere to watch with less people around.
So Rachel and I walked out and
found an advance person to ask if there was, like, another viewing area, because a lot of
times there will be multiple areas.
They showed us a tent, like, further, I guess it would be stage right, off in the back
from, like, a comms perspective or something.
So I went back and got her and Eric and Lara and we walked over to the other
And there wasn't really anyone in it other than the technicians, I guess,
And they went into the tent.
And then Rachel and I kind of were going in and out
And understanding that you weren't paying close attention to the speech,
did you hear, while the President was delivering his remarks, him say something to the
effect of he was going to go to the Capitol with the rallygoers after he was done
Did you hear him during the speech, as he was giving it, speak about Vice
President Pence and needing to have courage to do what he needed to do at the Capitol
After the President was done speaking, did you hear at any point before you
left the grounds there at the Ellipse about any disturbance at the Capitol, anything out of
the ordinary, like the discovery of a pipe bomb?
Anything of that make its way to you
Is it right that you got into the car again with Ms. Trump and Ms. Craddock
to drive back to the White House?
Do you remember about what time you got back?
context, the records we've seen show that the President himself arrived back at roughly
I was going to say probably, I mean, I was going to say 1:15, 1:20.
And how do you know it was before 1:45?
Because I was trying to order lunch.
And as we understand it, did Ms. Craddock go down to get lunch for
What time did they stop taking orders there?
That day I think they were just really busy and not understaffed, but I don't
know why, it was just really busy that day.
They normally stop around 2, but they hadn't
Before you arrived back -- I guess I should say before you left the Ellipse,
after President Trump got off the stage, did you interact with him at all?
enough to hear him interacting with other people?
So do you know whether during that time there was any discussion of him
At any point that day did you hear from anyone, whoever it was, that the
President had actually discussed going to the Capitol?
Did Ms. Trump come back up to her office when you all got back to the
Was Ms. Trump alone in her office working when Ms. Craddock went down
to get lunch, so far as you know?
And what was on the schedule that day for her, if you remember, that
Did Ms. Craddock end up bringing -- she was able to get the lunch and bring
When do you remember first learning that there was violence at the Capitol
or a problem or whatever word you want to use, that something was wrong?
Yeah, I was going to say, before or after she came back with the lunch?
I went into lvanka's office with a memo that I had written, like a transition
And then when, if you can remember, you first learned.
the day before and that morning.
It was, like, a ten-page document.
So at some point I went into her office so we could
I went back into my office.
And she had been reviewing and editing it
I had a text message that said, "Are you okay?" from
I didn't really know what he was talking about.
Then went -- the TV was on.
So then I, like, turned on the TV.
TV -- I wasn't really paying attention.
So the TV that was on, you had one in your office space?
Now, did you have one channel that was on, or was it the four-channel feed
And I could see something was going on, and I was
And then I went into her office.
that we know would be used elsewhere in the White House?
It would either be the four-channel -- the four-channel
or FOX, but I don't remember.
So what you saw was enough that -- on the TV and on your Twitter -- that
you got up and went to go talk to Ms. Trump about it?
And so what -- tell us about that.
with Ms. Trump when you went in.
What did you tell her, and what did the two of you
I just said something is going on.
that memo that I had written.
Tell me about that conversation you had
So then we got on Twitter and turned on the TV.
From what we were seeing, it was people going toward, like, at the Capitol, but it
wasn't -- like, you didn't see people in the Capitol, if that makes sense.
And then in that time period, while we were looking on Twitter, one of her
If I could stop right there.
And then -We know that Don Jr. tweeted and linked to a
story about the violence and said something to the effect of be peaceful.
Does that sound about right to you?
So then we said -- I don't know who said it, if it was me or her, but we
started working on something for her to write.
And it sounds like an obvious question, but what was the reaction that you
and she had to seeing what you were seeing on the TV and on social media to what was
know if they were Capitol Police.
I don't know what type of law enforcement they were.
And so she thought that same thing, like, this is not how we should be acting,
The images that we saw, it was more like -- I don't
Like we should like -- so she was
And was there any discussion at that time about the need for President
Trump himself to make a statement?
I don't remember talking about the President with her in that time period.
Just, I mean, my job was with her.
So it wasn't whether or not, you know, what he
So did you help craft a statement for Ms. Trump to put out?
We started working on something, and then she left the office.
Where did she leave to go?
I believe down to the Oval.
Why did she leave to go there?
I mean, I'm guessing it's because what was going on, on TV.
At some point -- and I believe it was Eric came in and got her.
So someone knocked on the door, and I believe it was Eric, and she went down -- Eric
I was standing in a corner.
Was anyone else in the office with you and Ms. Trump before
Rachel was there at one point, but I don't know what -- if it was before or
And so at the time that Mr. Herschmann came in, you-all had already been
seeing the events on the TV and had seen Don Jr.'s, his tweet about the violence at the
That had not -- it hadn't been very long, if that makes sense.
So when Mr. Herschmann came in the office, did he come
alone or did he have someone else with him?
And can you describe as best you can his demeanor and what he said when
Not really, because I, like where I was standing, the two of them, they talked
I can't really -- he just asked her, "Come with
Did it sound like a "come with me" in a calm way or was it in a hurried and
"this is important and we need to go now," just in terms of the way they were moving and
the manner in which they were speaking to each other?
But it wasn't panic, freak out.
So it's not like he was hair on fire.
But Eric is like a very solid, even-keeled
So, so far as Mr. Herschmann goes, for his personality and demeanor, you
could tell he was moving with urgency, but it wasn't a panicked state.
And where did he say they needed to go, that's he and Ms. Trump?
He didn't say, but I would -- I assumed downstairs to the President.
And did you understand why Mr. Herschmann was coming to get Ms. Trump
Did Ms. Trump come back to her office at some point that afternoon, after
Do you know approximately when that was?
but was it that afternoon, was it the evening?
And what did she tell you about when she
got back about what had happened, where she was?
That a tweet was sent out.
Sorry, by the President, asking people -- I think asking people to go home,
I didn't see the tweet at the time.
Why don't we just -- before we look at the tweet I will just ask, what did she
say, that is Ms. Trump say, she did with respect to the President and the tweet?
did she describe the meeting with her father?
She just said that a tweet had gone out.
Did she say at least where she met with him?
Did you learn at least some point that afternoon, before the day was over,
that the President had been in the private dining room off the Oval Office, that's where
Did Ms. Trump explain to you what the mood of her father was, what his
reaction was to what was happening at the Capitol?
Did she describe who else was with her when she met with her father before
Now, Mr. Herschmann had come to get her.
was there or anyone else was?
I know at one point, I don't know if it was at that exact time, Dan Scavino
and the chief of staff and Eric Herschmann, and that's -- those are the names I remember.
Did she then or at any point describe to you that there was resistance from
the President about sending the tweet out or particular language that he was resistant to
It's been reported and we have otherwise collected information, for
instance, that the tweet you're talking about, Ms. Trump was the one who suggested that
Does that ring any bell for you?
And that sounds like her, but I don't know.
At any point that day did you hear from Ms. Trump that her father was being
resistant to taking any action with respect to the violence at the Capitol?
Or from her that she felt the statements he was making were not sufficient
